    log1p and expm1 operations logsumexp trick

    log1p and expm1 operations

    logexp.Rmd
    library(Rutils)

    Two other operations that are common in machine learning research and prone to numerical instability are computing \(\log(1+x)\) and \(\exp(x)-1\) when \(x\) is very small. Rutils provides numerically-stable implementations of these two functions.

    Log1p

    Suppose that \(x=10^{-20}\). This value is small but large enough to be represented in a computer. However, since in floating-point arithmetic the numbers we are able to represent in a computer are not evenly spaced, the number \(1+x=1+10^{-20}\) will be represented as \(1\). Hence naive computation of \(\log(1+x)\) will return \(\log(1)=0\). The Log1p trick refers to the fact that, for small \(x\), \(\log(1+x)\approx x\). Rutils::Log1p checks if \(x\) is too small for \(1+x\) to be computed safely, and if it is then it approximates \(\log(1+x)\) with \(x\). See the example below:

    my_x <- 10^(-(10:20))
print(Log1p(my_x))
#>  [1] 1e-10 1e-11 1e-12 1e-13 1e-14 1e-15 1e-16 1e-17 1e-18 1e-19 1e-20
print(log(1+my_x))
#>  [1] 1.000000e-10 1.000000e-11 1.000089e-12 9.992007e-14 9.992007e-15
#>  [6] 1.110223e-15 0.000000e+00 0.000000e+00 0.000000e+00 0.000000e+00
#> [11] 0.000000e+00

    For values of \(x<10^{-16}\), the naive computation returns \(0\) but Log1p returns \(x>0\). Also note that Log1p is vectorized.

    Expm1

    Again suppose that \(x=10^{-20}\). Then the operation \(\exp(x)\) will return \(0\) since the computer is not able to represent such a small number. But using a Taylor’s expansion, \(\exp(x)\approx 1+x\). Again, we can approximate \(\exp(x)-1\) with \(x\) for sufficiently small \(x\), which Rutils::Expm1 checks automatically. See the example below:

    my_x <- 10^(-(10:20))
print(Expm1(my_x))
#>  [1] 1.000000e-10 1.000000e-11 1.000089e-12 9.992007e-14 9.992007e-15
#>  [6] 1.110223e-15 1.000000e-16 1.000000e-17 1.000000e-18 1.000000e-19
#> [11] 1.000000e-20
print(exp(my_x)-1)
#>  [1] 1.000000e-10 1.000000e-11 1.000089e-12 9.992007e-14 9.992007e-15
#>  [6] 1.110223e-15 0.000000e+00 0.000000e+00 0.000000e+00 0.000000e+00
#> [11] 0.000000e+00

    As before, for \(x<10^{-16}\) the naive computation returns 0 but Expm1 returns \(x>0\). The function Expm1 is also vectorized.
